newsitem.title: USA: Silicon Graphics targets software growth.
newsitem.headline: Silicon Graphics targets software growth.

text.p: Silicon Graphics Inc. CEO Edward McCracken said the company expects the size of its software applications business to grow four- to five-fold over the next five years.

"We'd like the applications side of our business to be in the $500 million range," McCracken told Reuters in an interview following the company's purchase of 3-D Internet graphics software pioneer ParaGraph International.

McCracken said the company's applications software business, which includes its newly formed Cosmo Software group and its AliasWaveFront entertainment and design software, now has around $100 million in revenues.
"This Web oriented activity has the potential to be explosive," the Silicon Graphics chief executive said of the new business unit created to focus on the area.
"Our company is really an innovative company. We intend to be a major player there," he said of the Internet.
McCracken said the company would continue to evaluate potential acquisitions, like ParaGraph, as well as growing its business internally. "We're always looking," he said.
McCracken said the company, which has reported a string of quarterly earnings disappointments amid a major product transition, now appears to picking up steam.
The CEO, who last week told Reuters he expects nice growth in revenues for this year's fourth quarter compared with the company's year-ago levels, declined to elaborate.
According to First Call, the Wall Street mean estimate for earnings per share in the fourth quarter is $0.36, off from $0.46 in the year-ago period.
